posts.body: And that’s it! We’re out. To sum up: new Mac Pro, new MacBook Pros, a new iPad Air, a Retina iPad Mini, a free upgrade to OS X Mavericks and upgrades to iWork and iLife. Oh yeah. And some covers too.

"This is what we mean by ‘Designed by Apple in California’" — Tim Cook

Mmmmm-hmmmm. So, um, take that Minnesota? I’m not really clear on this.

Tim is recapping everything now. No surprises, but a solid roll out.

Oh! And there’s a “cool new ad.” (And my editor just had an aneurism when Cook announced yet another video.)
Smart Covers and cases in a multitude of colors, but no keyboards shown. I guess that answers that rumor.

posts.caption: iPad min and iPad min with Retina. iPad mini now starting at $299.

posts.body: Retina iPad Mini with A7 surprises exactly no one, but still a welcome release.
They’re keeping the iPad 2 in the lineup at $399. That’s still not “cheap” (not that it needs to be). AT just $100 less than the iPad Air, I’m not sure why you’d buy that, but….

posts.caption: The iPad 2 and iPad Air price points.
The new A7 is inside the iPad Air.
Exploded view of the new iPad Air

posts.body: The new iPad is called the iPad Air. It’s almost 2 mm thinner than the previous one at 7.5 mm. In case you are wondering, that is indeed skinny. A7 chip too. Dang.
Phil is back to introduce the new iPads. Here we go.

"It’s really an amazing video and each of those scenes has an amazing story behind it" — Tim Cook.

Oh, phew, for a minute there I thought he was going to tell all of them.
Ah yes. A short video to celebrate the ways people use iPad. I’m just going to do a little interpretive dance now.
It’s true. People like iPads.

posts.caption: Tablet usage share. What’s the source Mr. Cook?

posts.text: When you make a great product, this is how you know it: People use it.

posts.body: Okay! So now we’re on to iPads. And Cook is serving up claim chowder from critics who predicted it would fail. Who is going to dox these quotes?

posts.caption: That’s a lot of iPads sold.

posts.body: Another free product: iWork is free for Mac and iOS. That’s a shot at Microsoft’s Office 365, but, really, given existing free tools like Google Docs and Prezi it’s not that big of a surprise to see Apple do this.

posts.caption: Tim is back. Please say iPads. Please say iPads.
Free! - with the purchase of computer or iOS device. Available today.

posts.body: Apple adds collaboration to iWork for iCloud, so, your boss can quit standing over your shoulder now.

posts.caption: Eddy - Coming to a coffee shop near you.

posts.text: Apple really knows how bad everyone wants to see the new iPads, which is why they’re having this extended discussion about spreadsheets.

posts.body: Roger is tucked in. He looks great.

Pages, Numbers, and Keynote all get updates. Cue notes that Keynote was used for today’s presentation. So, it’s a presentation about presentation software using the presentation software to present the presentation. Also, we just entered a wormhole.
iMovie and GarageBand do look like the interfaces have been simplified for both. I hope that translates to more ease of use, because both have gotten needlessly cluttered and complicated.
The guy giving the GarageBand demo onstage is named Zander Zorn. Or Xander Xorn. Or something. That’s an outerspace name if I ever heard one.

posts.caption: The new GarageBand looks like a Logic Pro X with Drummer.

posts.body: A GarageBand demo? Really? Um. I’m going to go get a coffee, y’all.

posts.caption: Picture-in-picture and speed up or slow down video on iPad or iPhone with the new iMovie.

posts.body: Cue notes that iLife and iPhoto is bringing PhotoBooks to the iPad. Seems like getting layout right on that would be tough.

posts.caption: Create a photo book on iPad with the new iPhoto.

posts.body: Eddie Cue? Untucked.

posts.caption: Eddie Cue is here to talks about iLife.

posts.body: $2999 for the MacPro, $1300 for the 13-inch MacBook Pro, $1999 for the 15-inch MacBook Pro, but hey the upgrade to Mavericks is free.

posts.text: The Mac Pro makes 4k real-time video editing a reality.

posts.caption: Shipping in December. Better update that list to Santa.

posts.body: Great, now I’m going to have to go out and buy a 4K TV to go with this thing.
Apple’s really diving into the specs on the Mac Pro (and rightfully; they’re impressive) but honestly I just can’t quit looking at it. Striking design.

posts.caption: The new Mac Pro next to the current Mac Pro.

posts.body:
Diamond cut chamfered edges!

(Drink)
The 13-inch MacBook Pro and 15-inch MacBook Pro are both Retina. Apple is really going all in on Retina. Clearly, they’re gradually taking the entire product line there.

posts.caption: The new 15-inch Retina MacBook Pro is shipping today.
The new 13-inch Retina Macbook Pro is shipping today.

posts.body: 9 hours of battery life for iTunes movie playback? That’s bananas. Schiller’s talking about watching the entire Dark Knight trilogy.
Phil Schiller is here to tell us about the MacBook Pros—and he is untucked in case you were wondering.

posts.caption: Phil Schiller on stage to talk about the MacBook

posts.body: Oh wow. Apple just announced that Mavericks is a free upgrade. That’s fantastic. No matter which system you’ve got, it’s a free, single-step upgrade and it’s available now. That’s really fantastic
Craig Federighi is rightfully doing a lot of demonstrations of Mavericks’ notifications. It really is a strong feature.

posts.caption: Creating a presentation for a mission to Mars. Clearly Apple is about to announce a space program.

posts.body: Craig Federighi is talking about the iBooks and Maps apps for Mavericks. I’m intrigued by the iBooks app, but I wonder how many people will really use it. Personally, I know I rarely use my Kindle desktop app (or the Kindle web app). But clearly Apple thinks there’s a demand for this. What do you think? Will you use a desktop book reading application?

posts.caption: Demoing updated OS X Notification alerts in Mavericks.

posts.body:
Craig Federighi has taken the stage to talk about OS X Mavericks and its improvements. So, we’re almost certainly going to hear a release date. 

Also Federighi totally reminds me of Fonzie.
Cook just took a slap at Microsoft and its Surface line, saying that they wanted to make PCs into tablets and tablets into PCs. (And presumably then back into tablets again? I’m not really sure.)

posts.caption: Craig Federighi takes the stage to talk OS X.

posts.body: One billion songs played on iTunes Radio in the last month. It’s an impressive sounding number, but I’d love more context there.
Cook’s back after showing us a video, noting that both of the phones shipped with iOS 7. He notes that it’s the biggest and fastest upgrade ever. But you knew that was going to happen, right?

posts.caption: Impressive percentage of iOs devices already running iOS 7.

posts.body:
Cook’s repeating what we already knew, that Apple sold 9 millioniPhones for its biggest opening weekend ever.

Cook is untucked, in case you were wondering. I guess I owe Calore $20
Apple’s kicking things off with a very clean black and white video that speaks to its ability to refine and perfect products that Cook says it first showed at WWDC in June. Hmmmmm.

posts.caption: Apple starts the event with a video about design

posts.body: It’s finally happened: I’ve gotten too old to recognize the music Apple is playing.

I don’t know about you guys but I think the thing I’m most excited about it to see if Tim Cook goes tucked in, or untucked today. 

Oh, and new iPads.
As you can see from Christina’s last photo, there are a whole lotta journo-nerds waiting to get in. It’s journo-nerd city at Yerba Buena today.
What do you expect to see today? Hit us with your thoughts on Twitter (we’re @Wired) and use the hashtag #aaplpredix and we’ll retweet the most interesting stuff you guys come up with.

posts.caption: Just chugged a cup of coffee. I also ate half a bagel. Things are real exciting right now.

posts.body: While we’re waiting to start, it’s worth going over what we expect to see today. A new full size iPad, a Retina iPad mini, a release date for Mac OS X Mavericks, new MacBook Pros and new Mac Pros all seem like safe bets. An iWatch? An Apple Television? An Apple TV? Eh. Probably not. But you can review our predictions here and hold our feet to the fire afterwards if we get it wrong
The press line is finally moving. It’ll still be about 45 minutes until we’re allowed into the theater though. Brr!

posts.caption: Here we are at today’s Apple event at San Francisco’s Yerba Buena Center. The weather today is kind of gross and foggy. Looking forward to getting some coffee and getting inside.
